section.title: Statewide Events
section.para: For statewide events, the SEC is notified by the Michigan State Police via E-Team notification when the SEOC is fully activated, or a need for amateur radio is perceived.
The SEC also monitors E-Team to be alert to incidents which may deteriorate to the point that SEC attention is required.

section.title: Local/Regional events
section.para:
For local or regional events, the affected EC should notify the DEC who will then notify the SEC by E-Team alert or by cell phone (989-430-4855). If the DEC is not available, the EC should notify the SEC directly. For events of lower urgency the EC or DEC may prefer email.
E-Team Alert is best
Since E-Team uses multiple paths, the best method of alert is through an E-Team targeted alert.

Even when a callout does not seem significant, the SEC should be notified. The SEC's broader view may allow him to alert ECs to issues not visible to the EC.
Keep eTeam up to date
The SEC monitors E-Team and uses it to update State officials during an incident. Be sure to keep your SitRep up to date.

section.title: SEOC Station Activation
section.para: When the SEOC is fully activated, the Michigan State Police notifies the station manager by pager. For other events, the SEC may notify the station manager by telephone as required.

section.title: SEC Staff Notification
section.para: As required, the SEC may notify the Assistant SECs by telephone.

section.title: Notifying the Districts
section.para:
The SEC will notify the DECs by E-Team notification. If time permits, those DECs who cannot be reached via E-Team will be notified by telephone. The E-Team notification list is as follows:

In addition, all the ASECs are included in that notification.
Follow E-Team
DECs are strongly encouraged to join E-Team themselves, and ensure at least one assistant DEC also is qualified for E-Team. Less than half of the DECs currently are qualified for E-Team.

section.title: National Weather Service Offices
section.para: Currently, none of the NWS DECs have E-Team capability. As a consequence, NWS DECs will be notified by telephone as appropriate.

section.title: Regional and Local Incidents
section.para: In the case of a regional or local event where the SEC becomes involved before the DEC, the SEC will typically notify the affected DEC by telephone. Depending on the incident, nearby DECs may also be notified.

section.title: DEC Contact Information
section.para: If it becomes necessary to directly contact an Emergency Coordinator, complete contact information for Emergency Coordinators is available in the SEOC Position Manual.

section.title: Notifying the Nets
section.para: Nets are notified as needed by telephone. On some occasions when weather is anticipated, some nets hold scheduled times and frequencies for monitoring and can be activated by radio.

section.title: Challenged Communications
section.para: When commercial communications are not available, the SEC will attempt to make notification on radiotelegraph and then radiotelephone immediately on notification of the incident, and then once per hour.

note.title: Radiotelegraph is far more reliable
note.para: Experience has shown that communications across the state on radiotelephone is often challenging. Stations should equip themselves for radiotelegraph communications whenever possible.

section.para: Radiotelegraph notification will occur on the hour and radiotelephone notification at 15 minutes after the hour, until such time as either the MIARPSC or QMN net has been fully activated, or until the SEC leaves for the SEOC.

row.entry: Summer, daytime, high flux. Lower frequencies are too noisy to support communications.
Winter, nighttime, low flux. Short skip (within state) is not possible on higher frequencies.

section.para: When the situation warrants, the DEC may also notify programs via the CMEN linked repeater system and/or the IRA link. Repeated notification, when required, will take place on the CMEN system at the bottom of the hour and the IRA system a 45 minutes after the hour.
